metadata.description: SingPost trades FMH, $5.1B Calisen acquisition, AVJennings buyout
metadata.emailHtml:
In today’s edition:

→ SingPost trades FMH

→ $5.1B Calisen acquisition

→ AVJennings buyout

 
 

HEADLINES

PEP to acquire SingPost’s FMH

Singapore Post Limited has agreed to sell its Australian logistics business, Freight Management Holdings (FMH), to Pacific Equity Partners (PEP) for $505.4 million. The deal values FMH at AUD1.02B and is expected to bring SingPost a gain of $233.1 million. PEP’s Managing Director expressed excitement about FMH’s growth potential. On the other hand, SingPost plans to use proceeds to repay AUD-denominated debt and may consider a special dividend.

EQT and GIC acquire Calisen

EQT and GIC are acquiring UK-based smart meter group Calisen, valuing it at £4B ($5.1B). Calisen, which specializes in smart metering, solar, EV charging, and data services, will exit from its current owners, BlackRock, Goldman Sachs Alternatives, and Mubadala. GIC’s interest follows its recent €6.7B acquisition of Techem, a German metering firm. The clean energy sector hit a record European PE deal value of €21B in 2024.

 
 

CHART

Tennis struggles with fragmented management and revenue disparities

The tennis world faces significant challenges due to its fragmented governance structure. Tennis operates under a divided system, unlike other sports with a centralized governance body like the NFL, NBA, or ICC (cricket). The four Grand Slams govern themselves; the International Tennis Federation oversees the Olympics and Davis Cup, while the ATP manages most other tournaments. This disjointed setup creates overlaps in revenue distribution and management.

As a result, tennis players receive just 17.5% of the $2.2 billion in annual revenue, starkly lower compared to the 47% earned by NFL players, 50% by NBA players, and 61% by Premier League (football) players. Without a centralized governing body to streamline operations, tournaments must independently manage infrastructure, advertising, and player engagement, limiting financial support.

 
 

BRIEFS

Private Equity

→EasyHotel sale nears £400M deal: Budget hotel chain easyHotel is close to being sold, with London & Regional Properties and Tristan Capital Partners vying for the £400M ($507M) deal. Owned by Ivanhoé Cambridge and ICAMAP, easyHotel has expanded to 50 locations across 11 countries since going private in 2019. London & Regional has 114 hotels across nine countries, and Tristan Capital Partners is no stranger to budget hotels. A decision is expected soon, with Rothschild overseeing the process. The representatives of either party have declined to comment on the ongoing process.

→AVJennings to go private in $374M buyout: Australian homebuilder AVJennings has accepted a $374M buyout offer from Proprium Capital Partners. The deal will merge AVJennings into Avid Property Group, diversifying its portfolio with land lease housing and addressing Australia’s housing shortages. The offer price of 67¢ per share represents a 108% premium over the three-month average. AVJennings shares surged 90% after the announcement. CEO Philip Kearns supports the deal, citing significant value realization for shareholders. Due diligence will continue until January, requiring approval from AVJennings’ chairman, Simon Cheong.

→EverSource Capital secures $1B for renewables: EverSource Capital has gained a $1B equity commitment from the US International Development Finance Corp (DFC) for its second renewable energy fund. Focused on energy storage, EV batteries, and industrial decarbonization, the fund aims to launch in 2025. EverSource’s CEO emphasized “purpose capital” for long-term sustainable investments, a shift from India’s short-term VC trends. The fund will target markets in Southeast Asia alongside India.

Hedge Funds

→Activist Metage pressures HVPE for change: Metage Capital is urging HarbourVest Global Private Equity (HVPE) to introduce quarterly exit options or face calls for liquidation. HVPE trades at a 40% discount to NAV, which Metage argues has doubled during the tenure of board chair Ed Warner. Metage suggests HVPE align with Luxembourg’s HarbourVest Global Private Solution fund, which allows 5% quarterly redemptions. HVPE’s reinvestment policy and strategy have been criticized despite delivering a 214% return over the past decade.

Venture Capital

→Bezos invests in Tenstorrent, rivals Nvidia: Jeff Bezos has joined Samsung in backing AI chip startup Tenstorrent with a $700M investment, valuing the firm at $2.6B. Led by semiconductor expert Jim Keller, Tenstorrent challenges Nvidia with RISC-V-based chips focused on cost-efficient AI development. While Nvidia dominates with proprietary tech, Tenstorrent bets on open-source solutions for interoperability. The startup plans a new processor every two years, aiming to disrupt Nvidia’s dominance in the AI chip market.

Others

→Biden offers $7.5B for Samsung-Stellantis hub: The Biden administration has proposed $7.54B in financing for StarPlus Energy LLC, a Samsung-Stellantis JV, to build two EV battery plants in Indiana. The funding, part of efforts to reduce dependence on foreign EV battery sourcing, aligns with Biden’s push for clean energy. However, the incoming Trump administration may threaten the deal. This follows a $6.6B loan for Rivian’s EV battery plant in Georgia, signaling strong federal support for domestic EV supply chains.

→Northern Star acquires De Grey Mining: Northern Star Resources is acquiring De Grey Mining in a $3.3B all-share deal, valuing De Grey at a 37% premium. The acquisition gives Northern Star full ownership of the Hemi project in Western Australia, set to produce 530,000 ounces annually over its first decade. This deal follows a wave of M&A in the gold sector, including AngloGold’s $2.5B Centamin acquisition.

 
 

FOUNDATIONS

Why does inflation erode the value of money over time?

Inflation erodes the value of money by reducing its purchasing power. In simple terms, as prices for goods and services rise, the same amount of money buys less over time. For example, what $100 could buy a decade ago is likely more than what it can buy today, reflecting the cumulative impact of inflation.

This happens because inflation, measured as the rate of price increases, affects both consumers and businesses. Factors like rising production costs, higher demand, or increased money supply can drive inflation. Central banks often target a modest inflation rate (e.g., 2%) to promote economic stability and growth, but excessive inflation—like in hyperinflation scenarios—can severely devalue money.

For savers, inflation is particularly concerning, as it diminishes the real value of cash and fixed-income investments. To counteract this, many investors turn to assets like stocks, real estate, or inflation-protected securities, which can better retain or grow value over time.

 
 

what is

Acid-test ratio

The acid-test ratio, also known as the quick ratio, measures how well a company can pay its short-term debts using its most liquid assets (like cash or things that can quickly turn into cash). If the ratio is 1, the company has just enough liquid assets to cover its liabilities. Imagine you had $100 in your wallet (liquid) and owed $100–you’d have an acid-test ratio of 1.

"Given a 10% chance of a 100 times payoff, you should take that bet every time." — Jeff Bezos

→ SingPost trades FMH

→ $5.1B Calisen acquisition

→ AVJennings buyout

 
 

HEADLINES

PEP to acquire SingPost’s FMH

Singapore Post Limited has agreed to sell its Australian logistics business, Freight Management Holdings (FMH), to Pacific Equity Partners (PEP) for $505.4 million. The deal values FMH at AUD1.02B and is expected to bring SingPost a gain of $233.1 million. PEP’s Managing Director expressed excitement about FMH’s growth potential. On the other hand, SingPost plans to use proceeds to repay AUD-denominated debt and may consider a special dividend.

EQT and GIC acquire Calisen

GIC’s interest follows its recent €6.7B acquisition of Techem, a German metering firm. The clean energy sector hit a record European PE deal value of €21B in 2024.
metadata.title: Dec 3: SingPost sells FMH, EQT acquires 5.1B Calisen, AVJennings absorption

metadata.emailHtml:
Did you know some of the most profitable investments today aren’t on Wall Street? Private equity is becoming mainstream.

On 5th Dec 2024 edition:

→ Hedge funds bet on yen

→ TPG’s $1.5B sale

→ ESR goes private

 
 

HEADLINES

Hedge funds short euro-yen

Hedge funds are increasingly betting on a stronger yen as speculation mounts over a potential Bank of Japan rate hike. Euro-yen options trading surged in recent weeks, with three-month implied volatility near its August peak. The shift away from dollar-yen trades stems from hawkish comments by BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda and fears surrounding a no-confidence vote in France. Investors are favoring cheaper option structures like put butterflies to hedge risks. The yen is trading near its strongest level since December 2023, making it a preferred currency against the struggling euro.

TPG’s potential sale

Private equity giant TPG is preparing to sell Crunch Fitness for over $1.5 billion, including debt. Partnering with Jefferies, the sale could kick off in early 2025, attracting interest from other PE firms. Crunch Fitness, founded in 1989, now boasts 460+ locations globally and $100M EBITDA. Recent sector deals include L Catterton buying Solidcore and 26North acquiring OneLife Fitness. Crunch’s valuation could exceed 15x EBITDA.

Learning Technologies goes private

General Atlantic is taking Learning Technologies Group private in a $1 billion deal, offering a 34% premium at 100 pence per share. The UK-listed ed-tech firm faced declining revenues as companies embraced generative AI and cut custom training budgets. LTG is delisting amid a wave of UK take-privates, with PE activity doubling to £14.7 billion this year. The move mirrors Just Eat’s delisting and follows high-profile acquisitions like EQT’s Dechra deal.

 
 

CHART

Bath & Body Works rebounds with strong earnings outlook

Bath & Body Works stock surged following an upbeat earnings report, signaling potential recovery for the retailer. The company posted $1.61 billion in revenue for Q3, marking a 3% increase year-over-year, while same-store sales declined by only 1.5%, the smallest drop since 2022 when the metric turned negative.

In a further positive move, the company raised its earnings-per-share guidance to $3.15–$3.28, up from $3.06–$3.26, reflecting improved confidence ahead of the crucial holiday season, traditionally the strongest period for retail.

 
 

BRIEFS

Private Equity

→ESR accepts $7B buyout bid: Hong Kong-listed ESR Group is set to go private in a $7 billion deal. A consortium led by Starwood Capital, Sixth Street, and Qatar Investment Authority will pay HK$13 per share, a 55% premium. The logistics real estate firm manages $154 billion in assets, focusing on warehouses and data centers in Asia-Pacific. ESR’s fragmented ownership delayed negotiations, but major shareholders, including Omers, agreed to sell.

→Carlyle plans $324M debt for acquisition: Carlyle Group is raising A$500 million ($324M) in debt to acquire Waste Services Group, an Australian recycling firm. The deal, valued at A$1 billion, highlights rising activity in Australia’s leverage buyout market. Carlyle is weighing bank loans or private credit for financing, following similar deals like Affinity’s A$515M Lumus Imaging takeover.

→Dubai billionaire invests $3B in Asia data: Dubai’s Damac Group, backed by Hussain Sajwani, is investing $3 billion in data centers across Southeast Asia. The initiative focuses on Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia to meet growing AI and cloud service demands. Damac’s unit, Edgnex Data Centers, is partnering with Nvidia to use its high-end Blackwell chips. With plans to expand globally, Edgnex aims to build a $5 billion digital infrastructure market.

Hedge Funds

→Balyasny hires Nomura rates trader: Olek Gajowniczek, a senior Nomura rates trader, has joined hedge fund Balyasny as a rates portfolio manager. The move follows multiple high-profile exits from Nomura’s rates desk, including EMEA head Ali Khan. Industry buzz suggests Khan might also join Balyasny.

→BlackRock invests $1.3B to keep talent: BlackRock is spending $1.3 billion on retention packages after acquiring HPS Investment Partners and Global Infrastructure Partners. The deals, valued at $25 billion, aim to expand its private credit and infrastructure assets to $600 billion. With top executives receiving equity incentives, CEO Larry Fink is focused on integrating new talent.

Venture Capital

→SpaceX plans $350B tender offer: SpaceX is preparing a $350 billion tender offer, marking a record year for secondary sales in VC-backed firms. The valuation reflects a $140 billion jump since its last sale. With $88 billion raised globally for secondaries in 2024, SpaceX’s move underscores the trend of unicorns tapping private markets for liquidity.

→Kardashians raise $10M for Khloud: Khloé Kardashian and Kris Jenner are raising $10 million for their new venture, Khloud. Already securing $4.49M, the startup’s trademarks hint at protein supplements in the form of popcorn and snack products. Bryan Baum of K5 Global is listed as CEO, with Michael Kives playing a key role. The Kardashian-Jenner family’s business acumen, seen with Kendall Jenner’s 818 Tequila, suggests another consumer hit.

Others

→Sabadell wins €358M lawsuit vs Cerberus: Banco Sabadell scored a legal victory over Cerberus, winning €358 million in a London court. The dispute centered on a 2018 real estate joint venture, with Sabadell alleging Cerberus failed to honor investment agreements. Cerberus plans to appeal, claiming the court misinterpreted the contracts. For Sabadell, this win strengthens its financial standing as it fends off BBVA’s takeover attempts.

→Italian tycoon ups stake in Monte Paschi: Francesco Caltagirone has increased his stake in Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA to 5%, surpassing Banco BPM SpA as a top shareholder. This move aligns with the Italian government’s strategy to privatize the bank and build a third major banking group.

 
 

FOUNDATIONS

Why do tech companies often trade at high price-to-earnings (P/E) ratios?

Tech companies frequently trade at high price-to-earnings (P/E) ratios because investors expect significant future growth. Unlike mature industries, many tech firms operate in innovative and rapidly expanding sectors, such as artificial intelligence, cloud computing, or biotechnology. This exponential revenue and earnings growth potential justify higher valuations today based on future profitability.

High P/E ratios also reflect the market's optimism about a company's scalability. Tech companies often have low marginal costs—once a product is developed, distributing it (e.g., software) can generate high returns without proportionally increasing expenses. For example, firms like Amazon and Tesla traded at elevated P/E ratios during their growth phases as investors priced in their long-term potential.

However, these valuations can also be risky. If growth slows or expectations aren’t met, stock prices may decline sharply. High P/E ratios signal optimism but should be evaluated alongside other metrics, such as cash flow and competitive positioning.

 
 

what is

Vertical analysis

Vertical analysis is a way to analyze financial statements by showing each line item as a percentage of a base figure. For example, on an income statement, you might show each expense as a percentage of total sales. Imagine you’re running a lemonade stand, and you find that sugar costs are 10% of your total sales–that’s vertical analysis. It helps you understand where your money is going relative to your overall revenue.

"Time is the friend of the wonderful company, the enemy of the mediocre." – Warren Buffett

 

Send us your feedback at readers@altdaily.co.

Interested in connecting with curious, informed readers? Advertise with us.

This newsletter is for informational purposes only and does not constitute financial advice.

 

30 N Gould St, Ste N, Sheridan, WY 82801, United States

metadata.title: Dec 5: Euro-yen trade, TPG sells fitness brand, 7B ESR buyout

metadata.emailHtml:
Did you know some of the most profitable investments today aren’t on Wall Street? Private equity is becoming mainstream.

In today’s edition:

→ Millennium invests in top traders

→ BlackRock’s all-stock acquisition

→ $39 Billion pension fund merger

 
 

HEADLINES

Millennium invests $3.3 billion in top traders

Millennium Management makes a $3.3 billion allocation to two new trading teams. Hong Kong-based Robert Tau will manage $1.5 billion exclusively for Millennium, while Daniel Engel-Hall will get $1.75 billion under the Andora Partners brand. Millennium has doubled its assets in the last 6 years and employs 330 investment teams globally. With tight risk limits and steady 12.5% returns in the past 11 months, the hedge fund giant remains a powerhouse in the industry.

BlackRock buys HPS in $12 billion deal

BlackRock acquires HPS Investment Partners in an all-stock deal worth $12 billion. The move positions BlackRock as a top-five private credit firm with $220 billion in assets. HPS’s founders will lead a new private financing unit, expanding BlackRock’s alternative assets to nearly $600 billion. This deal, along with recent acquisitions like Global Infrastructure Partners, signals BlackRock’s aggressive push into private markets.

 
 

CHART

China’s trade surplus keeps growing

China’s trade surplus has soared to unprecedented levels, reaching $785 billion in the first 10 months of 2024—a 16% increase from 2023 and the highest on record for this period. This surge highlights the export-driven nature of China’s economy, bolstered by manufacturers ramping up shipments ahead of peak season and potential tariff threats following Trump’s re-election. Exports in October exceeded expectations, while imports fell by 2.3%, reflecting weak domestic demand, slowing economic growth, and a shift among Chinese consumers toward domestic products.

This imbalance raises concerns of escalating trade tensions, as the U.S. considers tariffs of up to 60% on Chinese goods. A likely response from Beijing could include increased fiscal stimulus and further devaluation of the renminbi, which hit its lowest exchange rate against the dollar in a year.

 
 

BRIEFS

Private Equity

→TotalEnergies nears €2 billion VSB deal: TotalEnergies is close to acquiring VSB Group, a renewable energy project developer, for €2 billion ($2.1 billion). The German firm, owned by Partners Group, specializes in solar, wind, and hydro projects across Europe. This deal aligns with TotalEnergies’ strategy to expand in renewables, including offshore wind investments in Germany. This acquisition solidifies TotalEnergies’ commitment to the sector, following its €1.5 billion buyout of Total Eren last year.

→Carlyle-backed Abingworth launches $1.5 billion fund: Abingworth, supported by Carlyle, seeks to raise $1.5 billion for a fund targeting late-stage clinical trials. The fund aims to partner with major pharmaceutical companies in exchange for royalties from future drugs. Earlier this year, Abingworth struck deals with Gilead Sciences for cancer drug Trodelvy and Teva for asthma treatments, showcasing its focus on innovative healthcare solutions.

Hedge Funds

→Hedge fund founder joins Millennium in Asia: Ramesh Karthigesu, founder of Kaizen Capital, is shutting down his hedge fund to join Millennium Management as a senior portfolio manager. Known for Kaizen’s 15% annualized returns since 2020, Karthigesu will bring his team to the $70 billion hedge fund giant.

→Andurand hedge fund surges 23% in November: Pierre Andurand’s flagship fund soared 23% in November, erasing earlier losses and bringing its 2024 return to 13.8%. The Andurand Commodities Discretionary Enhanced Fund thrives on bold bets, such as cocoa and oil. Andurand’s cocoa bullishness paid off as prices hit record highs due to poor harvests in West Africa.

→Hedge funds shift from utilities to materials: Hedge funds are ditching utility stocks in favor of U.S. materials. According to Goldman Sachs, materials became the most net-bought sector last week, driven by chemicals, metals, and mining. Utilities, despite strong 2024 performance, are losing appeal as investors embrace growth-oriented sectors tied to industrial demand. With materials stocks gaining 9% year-to-date, the sector offers attractive opportunities amid evolving market dynamics.

Venture Capital

→Scope Labs launches venture capital arm: Scope Labs has launched Scope Labs Capital, a venture capital fund focusing on early-stage startups. Industry veteran Dave Sukoff, with decades of tech and finance expertise, joins as Chief Strategy Officer to lead this new initiative. Scope Labs has partnered with 20 early-stage companies and has tripled its engineering team since 2023.

Others

→Australian pension funds announce a $39B merger: Australia’s Equip Super and TelstraSuper are merging to form a $39 billion pension fund under the Equip Super brand. Equip Super manages $35 billion in funds and has 140,000 members in sectors including mining, automotive, energy, teaching, and healthcare.

→Investec raises €200 million for debt fund: Investec Alternative Investment Management has raised €200 million for its second private debt fund, PDF II. PDF II focuses on senior secured and subordinated debt to mid-sized corporates across Europe.

 
 

FOUNDATIONS

How does the Federal Reserve control the economy?

The Federal Reserve (Fed) controls the economy primarily through its monetary policy tools, which aim to maintain price stability, foster maximum employment, and promote moderate long-term interest rates. One key tool is adjusting the federal funds rate, which is the interest rate banks lend to each other overnight. The Fed makes borrowing more expensive by raising rates and slowing down consumer spending and business investment to cool inflation. Conversely, lowering rates stimulates borrowing and spending, promoting economic growth.

The Fed also uses open market operations, such as buying or selling government securities, to influence money supply and liquidity. Additionally, it can change reserve requirements—the amount banks must hold in reserve—directly affecting lending capacity. During economic crises, the Fed employs unconventional measures like quantitative easing to inject liquidity and stabilize financial markets. These actions help guide the economy, balancing growth and inflation while maintaining economic stability.

 
 

what is

Enterprise Value

Enterprise value (EV) is the total value of a company, including its equity (market value) and debt, minus its cash. It’s like the price you’d pay to buy the whole company, as it considers both what the company owns and what it owes. For example, if a company is worth $1 billion in stock value, has $500 million in debt, and $100 million in cash, its EV would be $1.4 billion.

"The stock market is filled with individuals who know the price of everything, but the value of nothing." — Phillip Fisher

 

Send us your feedback at readers@altdaily.co.

Interested in connecting with curious, informed readers? Advertise with us.

This newsletter is for informational purposes only and does not constitute financial advice.

 

30 N Gould St, Ste N, Sheridan, WY 82801, United States

metadata.emailHtmlPreview:
Did you know some of the most profitable investments today aren’t on Wall Street? Private equity is becoming mainstream.

In today’s edition:

→ Millennium invests in top traders

→ BlackRock’s all-stock acquisition

→ $39 Billion pension fund merger

 
 

HEADLINES

Millennium invests $3.3 billion in top traders

Millennium Management makes a $3.3 billion allocation to two new trading teams. Hong Kong-based Robert Tau will manage $1.5 billion exclusively for Millennium, while Daniel Engel-Hall will get $1.75 billion under the Andora Partners brand. Millennium has doubled its assets in the last 6 years and employs 330 investment teams globally. With tight risk limits and steady 12.5% returns in the past 11 months, the hedge fund giant remains a powerhouse in the industry.

BlackRock buys HPS in $12 billion deal

BlackRock acquires HPS Investment Partners in an all-stock deal worth $12 billion. The move positions BlackRock as a top-five private credit firm with $220 billion in assets. HPS’s founders will lead a new private financing unit, expanding BlackRock’s alternative assets to nearly $600 billion. This deal, along with recent acquisitions like Global Infrastructure Partners, signals BlackRock’s aggressive push into private markets.
metadata.title: Dec 4: Millennium’s 3.3B investment, BlackRock buys HPS, Pension fund merger

metadata.emailHtml:
Did you know some of the most profitable investments today aren’t on Wall Street? Private equity is becoming mainstream.

On 6th Dec 2024 edition:

→ Wall Street's hottest trade

→ Investors bet on energy assets

→ Hedge funds turn to doctors

 
 

HEADLINES

MicroStrategy’s $42B fund raise

MicroStrategy, led by Michael Saylor, is doubling down on Bitcoin, raising $42 billion in capital through equity and convertible bonds. Hedge funds are jumping on the convertible arbitrage opportunities created by the company’s volatile stock, which has surged over 500% this year. These convertible notes allow funds to profit from wild price swings tied to Bitcoin. However, critics warn of risks if the crypto rally reverses. Saylor continues to use MicroStrategy as a bridge between traditional finance and crypto markets, raising questions about the long-term sustainability of this high-stakes strategy.

Private equity offloads energy assets

Private equity firms are turning to continuation funds to offload aging energy assets with Baupost Group and Elliott Management leading deals. These funds extend ownership of hard-to-sell oil and gas properties, allowing investors to negotiate discounts while injecting fresh capital. Despite high interest rates and ESG concerns, opportunistic investors see potential in these volatile assets. With hopes of regulatory changes under Trump’s administration and cheaper debt financing, private equity players expect a rebound in the energy sector's M&A activity.

 
 

CHART

Berkshire Hathaway's cash pile reaches record $325 billion

Berkshire Hathaway, led by Warren Buffett, has amassed a staggering $325 billion in cash and cash equivalents, the highest in its history. This comes after selling $36 billion in stock holdings during Q3 2024, including a significant reduction in its Apple stake for the fourth consecutive quarter. The immense cash reserve underscores Buffett’s cautious outlook on current investment opportunities, favoring cash and U.S. Treasuries over equities.

To put this cash hoard into perspective, it surpasses the market valuations of companies like Starbucks ($112 billion) and Target ($69 billion) and could theoretically acquire all 32 NFL teams at a 50% premium to their collective value.

 
 

BRIEFS

Private Equity

→Private equity launches new football agency: Bruin Capital and TJC have created AS1, a London-based football agency managing over 300 players, including stars like Bruno Fernandes. The $309 million venture merges four agencies, reflecting growing private equity interest in European football. This trend has seen private investors backing 33 out of 96 clubs in top leagues as multi-club ownership rises. With player transfers earning agents $888 million in 2023, AS1 is set to capitalize on football’s lucrative opportunities.

→TPG invests $2B in Veeam Software: TPG is leading a $2 billion secondary investment in Veeam Software, valuing the data resilience firm at $15 billion. Known for its cloud-based data protection services, Veeam has over 550,000 customers globally.

Hedge Funds

→Hedge funds hire doctors for pharma insights: Hedge funds like Balyasny and Point72 are hiring doctors and scientists to gain an edge in analyzing volatile pharmaceutical stocks. This trend follows significant stock movements driven by drug trial updates, such as AbbVie’s 11% drop after a failed trial and Novo Nordisk’s 7% rise after strong sales.

→Dymon Asia opens Dubai hedge fund office: Singapore-based Dymon Asia Capital is expanding to Dubai, attracted by the emirate’s tax-free status and strategic time zone. Managing $3 billion in assets, Dymon focuses on equities, credit, and macro strategies. With a 13.4% return year-to-date, the firm plans for further regional growth.

→Pershing Square Holdings to delist in Amsterdam: Pershing Square Holdings, managed by Bill Ackman, plans to delist from Amsterdam’s Euronext, consolidating trading on the London Stock Exchange. Valued at $10 billion, the fund focuses on concentrated investments in North American companies.

Venture Capital

→Lawhive secures $40M for US expansion: Legal tech startup Lawhive has raised $40 million in a Series A round led by GV and TQ Ventures. The London-based company automates legal tasks for lawyers using its AI tool, “Lawrence.” The legal tech sector has seen record VC funding this year, marking an estimated market value of $1 trillion annually.

→Sola raises $3.7M to transform insurance: Insurtech company Sola has closed a $3.7 million seed round to make natural disaster insurance affordable and reliable. The funding, led by FINTOP Capital, supports the expansion of Sola’s wind and hail coverage, targeting high-risk states. Sola uses advanced weather data and automated claims processing for faster payouts, offering relief to homeowners struggling with rising premiums.

Others

→Stake opens Saudi real estate to investors: Dubai-based firm, Stake, is bringing fractional ownership to Saudi Arabia, allowing investors to enter its real estate market with just $134. Backed by Mubadala and Saudi Aramco Ventures, Stake pursued deals worth 1 billion riyals, including a mall in Riyadh. With apartment values surging 62% in Riyadh over three years, the platform offers rental yields of up to 8%.

→Interest rate cuts to revive global M&A: Global M&A activity is set to rebound in 2025 as easing interest rates create opportunities across sectors, according to Ocorian. A survey of 19 countries found that 75% of executives expect deal-making to increase, driven by inflation relief and lower financing costs.

 
 

FOUNDATIONS

How does the LIBOR rate affect global financial markets?

The London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) has historically been a critical benchmark for global financial systems, influencing the cost of borrowing and lending worldwide. It represents the average interest rate banks charge each other for short-term loans in the interbank market.

LIBOR affects trillions of dollars in financial contracts, including mortgages, credit cards, corporate loans, and derivatives. For instance, variable-rate loans often use LIBOR as a reference, meaning fluctuations in the rate directly impact borrowing costs for businesses and individuals.

Its role extends to derivatives markets, where it serves as a benchmark for pricing instruments like interest rate swaps and futures. These tools help businesses and financial institutions manage risks.

However, due to manipulation scandals and declining relevance, LIBOR is being phased out and replaced by alternative rates like SOFR (Secured Overnight Financing Rate).

 

FUN FRIDAYS

Inside Job

On the surface, Inside Job might appear to be just another movie on the 2008 financial crisis. But this Academy Award-winning film digs deep into the complexities of global finance, revealing the interconnectedness of Wall Street, politics, and academia. Narrated by Matt Damon, it uncovers how reckless risk-taking, deregulation, and unethical practices brought the global economy to the brink of collapse.

What sets Inside Job apart is its ability to break down intricate financial concepts—like credit default swaps and subprime lending—into digestible explanations. It doesn’t just explain what happened; it interrogates the "why," exposing systemic greed and negligence.

A must-watch for finance enthusiasts, this film isn’t just educational—it’s a sobering reminder of the impact of unchecked power in the financial system. Watch Inside Job to understand the real story behind one of the most devastating financial crises in history.

 
 

what is

Adverse selection

Adverse selection happens when one party in a transaction has more information than the other, leading to a potentially unfair deal. For instance, if a seller knows a car has hidden problems but the buyer doesn’t, the buyer might overpay. It’s common in insurance, where insurers worry about only unhealthy people signing up for health coverage.

"The real measure of your wealth is how much you’d be worth if you lost all your money." – Jiddu Krishnamurthy

 

Send us your feedback at readers@altdaily.co.

Interested in connecting with curious, informed readers? Advertise with us.

This newsletter is for informational purposes only and does not constitute financial advice.

Photo by Amazon Prime Video.

 

30 N Gould St, Ste N, Sheridan, WY 82801, United States

Copyright © 2024 Sagravia LLC, All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Dec 6: MicroStrategy’s Bitcoin payoff, Oil investment, Hedge funds hire doctors
